title: 107_hr5687
content: The Act titled "Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal Land Conveyance Act of 2002" is referred to as the short title. It pertains to the conveyance of land related to the Blunt Reservoir and Pierre Canal. The Blunt Reservoir feature of the Oahe Unit, James Division, authorized by the Act of August 3, 1968, is defined as a nonpreferential lease parcel purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir feature or the Pierre Canal feature. The term "Governor" refers to the Governor of the State or a designee. The term "preferential leaseholder" refers to a person or descendant who held a lease on a preferential lease parcel as of January 1, 2001, reflected on the Bureau of Reclamation's 2001 roster. The term "unleased parcel" refers to land purchased by the Secretary for use in connection with the Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal features that is not currently under lease. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior, acting through the Commissioner of Reclamation. The term "State" refers to South Dakota, including any successors. The Blunt Reservoir feature is deauthorized, and the State of South Dakota must accept ownership and liability for certain features as a condition of conveyance. The State of South Dakota must accept ownership and liability for outstanding obligations associated with expired easements or rights granted in, on, over, or across certain features. The state is also responsible for administering purchase options for preferential leaseholders. Outstanding obligations shall benefit the state, and conveyances or sales to the state or preferential leaseholders are subject to reserved oil, gas, and mineral rights. The conveyance to the State under subsection (d)(5) or (e) is subject to reservations by the United States and conditions specified in the Act of May 19, 1948 for wildlife conservation purposes. A preferential leaseholder has a purchase option. A preferential leaseholder has the option to purchase the preferential lease parcel from the Governor, acting as an agent for the Secretary, on either a cash purchase or installment purchase basis. The purchase price is determined based on the parcel's value minus 10 percent. The preferential leaseholder can purchase the parcel on a cash or installment basis, with a 10 percent discount on the parcel's value. For parcels under $10,000, the purchase must be made in cash. The leaseholder has 5 years to exercise the purchase option after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary can lease the parcel to the preferential leaseholder under the same terms as the existing lease. The value of the parcel will be determined by an independent appraisal, excluding any private improvements made by the leaseholder while the land was federally owned. Any disputes over the fair market value will be resolved according to federal standards. If a preferential leaseholder fails to purchase a parcel within the specified period, the Secretary will convey it to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation. Proceeds from land sales will be used accordingly. Proceeds from land sales under this Act will be deposited into the Treasury as miscellaneous funds and made available to the State for establishing a trust fund to pay county taxes on lands received by the State Department of Game, Fish, and Parks. The Secretary will convey nonpreferential lease parcels and unleased parcels to the South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks for wildlife habitat mitigation within a year of the Act's enactment. The South Dakota Department of Game, Fish, and Parks will use land conveyed for wildlife habitat mitigation due to the Pick-Sloan project. The Governor may allow land exchanges for nonpreferential lease parcels or unleased parcels at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal. Priority for exchanges will be granted in a specific order. Priority for land exchanges at Blunt Reservoir or Pierre Canal will be granted in a specific order, including exchanges with current lessees and adjoining landowners. A perpetual easement for water conveyance structures is reserved by the United States as a condition of the exchange. The Pierre Canal feature is subject to release from liability under the Act, with exceptions for acts of negligence. The United States will not incur additional liability beyond the Federal Tort Claims Act. Requirements for conveying lease parcels are outlined during a specific timeframe. The Secretary will continue to lease parcels under current terms until conveyance. Parcel descriptions must be provided to the State within 180 days. $750,000 is authorized for implementation expenses. The Governor can be reimbursed for expenses up to 10% of each transaction under this Act.
